description.narrative: Sudan is facing one of the worst flooding situations seen for more than 70 years. According to initial reports approximately 100 people have died, at least 100,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed, and more half a million people are affected. These figures are expected to increase significantly as access to the affected areas remains extremely challenging and assessments are still ongoing. Humanitarian needs are rapidly increasing as the country faces multiple shocks beside the floods, including the economic crisis, violence and disease outbreaks, and more rainfall is expected. The Government of Sudan has declared a three month nationwide state of emergency, appealing for assistance from civil society and humanitarian national and international organizations to respond to the flood affected population. Almost every state has been affected and according to the Ministry of Irrigation, the river Nile recorded the highest water level in Khartoum since 1912, over 17.62 metres. Rapid needs assessments indicate significant damage to houses, properties and livelihoods, disruption of transport networks, roads and water and sanitation infrastructure, and lack of access to markets and health care facilities.
